nodes.name: Jakob Kukula
bio: Jakob Kukula is a multidisciplinary creator, working in the fields of art, design and music. Born and raised in Berlin, he has always been influenced by the city’s thriving scenes. After finishing his product design studies at the Bauhaus University in Weimar, that included abroad experiences at the Pratt Institute, NY and working with Studio Drift in Amsterdam, he returned to Berlin where he worked two years with the Studio Olafur Eliasson and finished his MA Thesis at KHB Weißensee.

As Founder of SpreeBerlin and Symbiotic lab, he currently explores a planet-centric practice; questioning the relationship between humans and nature, seeking ways to reconnect and suggesting ideas for transformation by combining art, design and science.

nodes.name: Marina Wainer
bio: Marina Wainer is a French-Argentinian artist based in Paris. For the last 20 years, she has been creating interactive artworks at the nexus of art, technology, and society. Taking a sensitive approach and working with communities, she explores societal issues and spaces of representation, designing experiences where the audience is at the heart of the work.

Her recent work focuses on inclusive approaches to generative AIs, through the creation of narratives and imaginaries, in fictional spaces that question these language models and open up new perspectives. Over the years, Wainer has developed transdisciplinary collaborations with researchers and scientists. Her work has been exhibited in various cultural and academic contexts in France, Argentina, Iceland, England, Belgium, Colombia, Finland and Taiwan.
Alongside her artistic production, she has carried out spatial and interaction design projects, and devoted part of her activity to teaching and designing events related to her practice.

nodes.name: Anna Dumitriu
bio: Anna Dumitriu is an award winning internationally renowned British artist who works with BioArt, sculpture, installation, and digital media to explore our relationship to healthcare, climate-change and emerging technologies. Past exhibitions include ZKM, Ars Electronica, BOZAR, The Picasso Museum, HeK Basel, Nobel Prize Museum, MOCA Taipei, LABoral, Art Laboratory Berlin, and Eden Project. Anna's work has featured in significant publications including Frieze, Artforum International Magazine, Leonardo Journal, The Art Newspaper, Nature and The Lancet.

Anna holds a visiting research fellowship at the University of Hertfordshire, and artist-in-residence roles with the Modernising Medical Microbiology Project at the University of Oxford and she was the 2018 President of the Science and the Arts Section of the British Science Association. Collaborations include the Institute of Microbial Biotechnology at BOKU University Vienna, the University of Leeds and Brighton and Sussex Medical School.

nodes.name: Lucie Hernandez
bio: Lucie is an artist researcher developing tools and technologies to encourage more responsible, sustainable approaches to textiles and clothing. Her research focuses on craft processes, material qualities, reuse and repair skills to facilitate projects that explore new human-material relations.

Lucie holds a background in human-computer interaction, designing tangible interfaces for embodied interaction. Her PhD combined the dynamic properties of computation with textiles to demonstrate the possibilities for technological materials to extend sense perceptions and suggest new design contexts.

Lucie addressed sustainable practices for interactive textiles in environmental and social contexts for WEAR Sustain, an EU Horizon 2020 Research and Development Programme, promoting the co-development of ethical and sustainable wearable technologies and e-textiles. She used the opportunity to develop a socially engaged design practice to work cooperatively with a broad range of people and involve them in the design process. Lucie's work revealed the value in developing co-produced design outcomes and processes with digital technologies, exploring attitudes to sustainable behaviour, imagining future scenarios with groups of users in the co-design of products and services.

nodes.name: Ruth Catlow
bio: Ruth Catlow is the co-founder and director of Furtherfield. In this role, she has organised for nearly 30 years for inclusivity and equity in art and technology, advocating for their use in imagining and building real social change and positive environmental impact. Furtherfield’s mission is to open up the tools and debates of the exclusionary realms of art and technology for collective action for collective good.

In Ruth's artistic work, she develop processes for critical group-driven discovery and playful co-creation that embrace more than human interests for fairer and more connected cultural ecologies and economies. Projects include: Live Action Role-Plays (LARPs) for planetary-scale interspecies justice; the CultureStake decentralised app for collective cultural decision-making; books such as Radical Friends – Decentralised Autonomous Organisations and the Arts (2022) and Artists Re:thinking the Blockchain (2017).

nodes.name: Camille Baker
bio: Camille is Professor of Interactive and Immersive Art at the Royal Collage of Art in London UK. She is an interdisciplinary digital artist, curator and researcher in Immersive Experiences, Interactive Art, XR design, interactive art, participatory performance, e-textiles, emerging technologies, and digital art curating – across creative disciplines – now primarily focussed on XR artworks on women’s healthcare stories, to validate patients’ experiences and create empathy in others.

nodes.name: Lizbeth Goodman
bio: Chair of Creative Technology Innovation & Director of SMARTlab, University College Dublin, where she directs the Inclusive Design Research Centre of Ireland at UCD, in partnership with SMARTlab clg and the Academy4theFuture. She is Chair of EDI for SMME and is an Athena Swan programme representative for Engineering & Architecture. Lizbeth founded the SMARTlab in its first iteration in 1992 and has developed the award-winning practice-based PhD Programme through the institute, along with the associated MAGIC Multimedia and Games Innovation Centre and Gamelab, which Lizbeth designed with industry collaborators as a prime knowledge transfer space in the London docklands prior to moving the lab to Dublin in 2010-11. Lizbeth and her teams specialise in developing ground-up technology solutions with and for people of all levels of cognitive and physical ability. in all her work, she applies an inclusive design method to practice-based innovation to transform lives through providing unlimited access to education and tools for creative expression.

nodes.name: Hua Dong
bio: Dr Hua Dong is Professor in Design and Director of Brunel Design Research Centre. She was elected Vice-Chair of the Design Research Society  (DRS) in 2024. Trained at Univeristy of Cambridge, Hua Dong specialises in inclusive design. She founded the inclusive design research group at Brunel University and Tongji University.

Her research contributed to the  Design Council's 'Design Bugs Out' Challenge, with successful products on market and exhibition at the Design Museum. Hua introdcued 'Fixperts' to teaching at three univeristies, facilitating design students to work with critical users/local communities to solve real-world problems. As the AHRC SEED Fellow, Hua promotes UK-China creative industries research and innovation collaboration. Hua is the Brunel's Principal Invetigator of the VOICE project (https://voice-community.eu/).

nodes.name: Maro Pebo
bio: Maro Pebo (Mariana Pérez Bobadilla) curates exhibitions, projects, and events in art and science at Waag. She develops learning situations where artist-led innovation supports critical perspectives on technoscience. She is an artist and art historian specialising in the cultural dimensions of the life sciences. Maro was born in Mexico City and holds a Ph.D. in Creative Media (City University of Hong Kong) and an MA in Critical and Gender Studies (Bologna University). Her trans-disciplinary work complements and transforms the life sciences' responsibility to think about the materiality of the living.

nodes.name: Anita McKeown
bio: Dr Anita McKeown, artist, academic and systems thinker, bringing 30 years of practice across education, community, and cultural sectors. Her work integrates STEAM, place-based learning and trauma-informed methodologies. Co-author of Trauma-Informed Placemaking (Routledge, 2024) with Dr Cara Courage, Anita's practice supports inclusive, regenerative futures through co-creation and critical care.

As Director of SMARTlab Skelligs,  an elected fellow of the RSA and the Institute of Place Management, she is committed to cultivating belonging and resilience through ethical, participatory arts and design across diverse and marginalised communities.
nodes.connections: SMARTlab UCD and SMARTlab Skelligs (split site host resesarch organisation for UCD)

nodes.name: Zeynep Birsel
bio: Zeynep Birsel is concept and project developer for the Open Design Lab and Space Lab at Waag. She has over fifteen years of professional experience in working with scientists, academic entrepreneurs, start-ups and mid-size companies in commercial development of early stage technologies and designing for sustainable innovation. She is also experienced in policy development for regional innovation. Currently she is also a PhD researcher at Erasmus University. Her research focuses on art-science-technology collaborations, how they form and function. Her recent work at Waag heavily involves designing and implementing artist residencies under the S+T+ARTS scheme.

nodes.name: RiverSync
description: Jakob Kukula’s RiverSync is a transdisciplinary artistic intervention focused on river systems as ecological, legal, and cultural actors. Over the course of six months, RiverSync used participatory design, environmental sensing, and community storytelling to foster new relationships between urban residents, river systems, and legal frameworks. The project was centred on the Spree River in Berlin but extended to include international connections with water justice movements.

RiverSync invited communities to listen to the river, and to imagine what it would mean if rivers had voices, rights, and legal standing. The project brought together students, artists, legal scholars, and Berliners from different backgrounds to reimagine the Spree River not as a background element of the city, but as a living actor in its own future. Workshops became experiments in co-creating water law, sensors became poetic instruments, and the river became a character in its own story. Through storytelling, sensing, and legal imagination, RiverSync aimed to enable people to reframe their relationship with the river, from passive observers to active stewards. The project operated in collaboration with the network of European water bodies—a young coalition of 15 water initiatives advocating for the rights of water bodies across Europe—and engage Berlin's citizens, students from the TU, as well as the Motion Lab community, a start-up makerspace hub in Berlin.
nodes.who_involved: Confluence, a network of European water bodies, as well as Berlin's citizens, students from the TU, and the Motion Lab community - a start-up makerspace hub in Berlin.
nodes.legacy_impacts:
Interdisciplinary reach (legal, technological, poetic)
Highly iterative methodology shaped by feedback
Publicly reusable tools and platforms
Contributions to both local and international Rights of Nature dialogue
nodes.challenges:
Maintaining clarity in public workshops while navigating speculative content
Technical breakdowns of sensors in winter conditions
Balancing the poetic with the actionable, especially in legal translation contexts
Short-term nature of the project and maintaining relationships and dynamics post project
nodes.methods: Speculative-future workshops, River-centred meditation, Participatory mapping, Storytelling, Water Sensor Module Design

nodes.name: Synocene — beyond the Anthropocene
description: Synocene is a collaborative work* that explores a de-centered view of our anthropocentric experience of the natural world. Voices of local communities, the sounds of Natura 2000 forests, and the contributions of artificial intelligence all work to imagine a future beyond the Anthropocene. Artist Marina Wainer’s Synocene took place in Ulvenhout Forest, a protected nature site in the Netherlands. The project invited people of all ages to take a walk in the woods to explore new forms of interaction with natural ecosystems in a transformed state that questions our appearance, our perception, and our language.

These participants then worked with an artificial intelligence engine to envision narratives of a more-than-human world. The project embedded AI used as a fictional tool, which allowed the workshop participants to question our anthropocentric vision of the natural world, against the backdrop of a pivotal moment - the passage from the Anthropocene to the ‘Synocene’. A new era where all ‘other voices’ come together, where humanity's relationship with other forms of life or existence has changed.  Participants wore reflective masks, used binaural sound, and interacted with an AI designed to speak as if it were a tree, a mushroom, or a stream - to change perceptions during the walk, as the forest has conversations with them within a fictional framework. These forest characters were intended to spark thoughtful, creative discussions about our relationship to nature, the role of technology, and how we might live more sustainably.

Over the course of a week in December 2024, 37 participants, ranging from children to conservationists, joined Wainer and her team for forest walks, and AI storytelling sessions. The AI system, designed to speak and respond in Dutch, was specifically built to be accessible to young and neurodiverse users. It allowed people to imagine themselves in dialogue with more-than-human beings, and in doing so, to reflect on their own environmental values. Synocene created a space where communities could come together, listen to the forest, and imagine new narratives about what it means to live well in a changing world.

* The project has been developed by artist Marina Wainer and trumpet player, composer and sound artist Sam Nester, in collaboration with Isabelle Hupont, AI specialist at the JRC, and Lucia Iglesias Blanco, policy officer at Natura 2000, as part of the JRC SciArt Resonances IV programme.
nodes.who_involved: Ulvenhout forest communities; Breda Nieuwe Veste communities; local nature conservationists. Sabine van der Hoorn, Sylvie Tissot, Zoé Pasquier, Nathan Marcus, Sam Nester, Ronald Lanters, Saskia Meijs, Erica Bol, Karlijn Muller, Patty & Marc Aartsen, Gerben van Ooijen.
nodes.legacy_impacts:
Conducted 8 inclusive, multilingual workshop sessions with participants.
Created 5 AI chatbot forest personas using speculative fiction and local biodiversity data.
Developed a Dutch-language AI interface with both text and voice capabilities.
Established the 'community table' model for non-hierarchical, intergenerational dialogue.
Incorporated ethical AI design considerations into workshop structure and discussions.
Fostered new partnerships with Nieuwe Veste Breda, local schools, forest managers, and cultural institutions.
Initiated plans for a future presentation of the sound installation as part of a public exhibition.
Contributed to VOICE goals on citizen agency, biodiversity dialogue, and creative technological critique.
nodes.challenges:
Language and Cultural Nuance: Language barriers; Translation into Dutch revealed systemic biases in AI interaction, impacting inclusivity; AI limitations in translation and embedded bias; and Cultural difference when re-siting / transferring project concepts.
Infrastructure Constraints: Short time-line (3 months) limited opportunity to explore partnerships with local environmental organisations to expand the project's influence and sustain its outcomes.
Finding a venue near the forest with accessibility and affordability created logistical tension. Some community sectors were slower to respond, requiring sustained outreach and flexibility.
AI Ethical Concerns: Navigating participant understanding of fictional AI, consent for interaction, and expectations required significant facilitation.
nodes.methods: Forest Walking, AI Storytelling Workshops, Participatory Speculative Design, Co-created storytelling and co-created narratives, Multilingual interface, Sound recordings / sound data collection

nodes.name: Greening the Lab: Decarbonising Biomedical Science
description: Anna Dumitriu's project, Greening the Lab: Decarbonising Biomedical Science (GTL), is an art-led response to the ecological footprint of the biomedical sector. The artistic intervention responds to an urgent need from the biomedical research community to create novel solutions and increase stakeholder support via their patient and public engagement (PPE) communities for artist-led actions towards decarbonisation of biomedical science and healthcare settings. The project targets critical approaches to biomedical waste, such as single-use plastic items and other materials, commonly discarded in biomedical research and how these can be reused.

With laboratories producing substantial waste, especially through single-use plastics and metals—the project sought to interrogate these issues through participatory, interdisciplinary artistic interventions. Working with three biomedical communities (Brighton and Sussex Medical School, University of Leeds, and University of Oxford), GTL aimed to co-create sustainable strategies for biomedical waste through experimental workshops that integrated science, technology, and artistic practice.

By convening public, clinical, and artistic communities to explore the intersection of infection control and sustainability, the project framed biomedical decarbonisation as both a technical and deeply human concern.
nodes.who_involved: University Hospitals Sussex NHS Foundation Trust, Leeds University Healthcare Associated Infection Research Group, Brighton and Sussex Medical School (BSMS)
nodes.legacy_impacts:
The innovative methodologies developed, particularly the open-source sharing of bioplastic recipes and reuse protocols, offer valuable assets for continued application and further research in biomedical sustainability practices.
In addition, GTL set an exemplary precedent for integrating artistic methodologies into biomedical and environmental policy discussions.
Community and institutional partners recognised the project's potential to inform practices and with sustained evidence and quantitative measurement, also policies around clinical waste management and sustainable procurement.
This positions GTL as a practical, replicable model with profound implications for future interdisciplinary collaboration.
nodes.challenges:
Initial scepticism by lab professionals around handling of biomedical waste / biosafety by lay person.
Delays due to autoclave malfunction and tight schedules for workshop participation across diverse sites and participants.
Complex health and safety and ethical considerations around contamination and reuse impacting access to materials and sterility requirements.
Need for institutional infrastructure, to navigate biosafety compliance and the complexity of bio-medical regulations.
Navigating NHS institutional structures and compliance.
Long-term impacts could not yet be measured within the 6-month timeframe.
nodes.methods: Biomaterial workshops, Storytelling, Critical Making, Biomaterial processing, Open-source protocols, Strategic Dissemination at Symposiums and Public Events

Funded by the Horizon Europe VOICE Project (https://www.voice-community.eu/).
Funded by the European Union under Grant Agreement No.101135803.

nodes.name: Designing E-textile Practice Samplers
description: Designing E-textile Practice Samplers (DEPS) was led by artist and researcher Lucie Hernandez in partnership with Ealing Repair Café. It explored how co-creation, digital tools, and community-led making can support sustainable clothing repair. Initially centred on developing e-textile practice samplers, the project evolved in response to the community's values and interests, focusing instead on visible mending, upcycling, and digital storytelling.

Through weekly workshops, informal co-creation, and the use of accessible technologies like WhatsApp and QR codes, Lucie worked closely with volunteers to co-produce a range of creative outputs. These included collaboratively made upcycled samples and garments, filmed tutorials, and QR-coded mending guides. These resources are now being used by ERC and shared with wider audiences online.

DEPS has a lasting impact in helping ERC strengthen their organisational identity, develop a new digital presence, and expand their community offerings. Volunteers gained confidence in teaching and public engagement, and new opportunities have emerged for ERC to act as a knowledge hub for individuals and other repair groups.

This collaboration shows how artist-led work can spark long-term change when built on mutual respect, adaptability, and shared creativity. The tools, methods, and relationships developed here can be used by others interested in sustainable fashion, repair culture, and community action.
nodes.legacy_impacts:
Legacy was embedded throughout the project via the development of sustainable practices and the handover of tools.
ERC volunteers continue to use the QR-coded toolkit and videos, while also building capacity to lead future workshops.
The project also left an organisational legacy by influencing ERC's internal organisation and external engagement strategies.
The co-created materials, especially the tutorial videos and textile artefacts, became not just educational tools but also vehicles for ERC to express their ethos, aesthetics, and approach to repair and sustainability.
This with the workshop discussions, fashion show participation and the instagram account encourages ERC to become more deliberate about storytelling, values, and audience interaction.
nodes.challenges:
Scheduling difficulties and variable volunteer availability.
Initial misalignment between e-textile focus and community expectations.
Importance of iterative co-design grounded in community values.
nodes.methods: Repair and Reuse Textile Workshops, Community Mapping and Social Media, Reflective Practice, Participatory Mapping, Participatory Design workshops, Digital storytelling

nodes.name: Felixstowe Youth VOICE
description: Building on the 5-year immersive fiction The Treaty of Finsbury Park, Felixstowe Youth VOICE is a six-month arts project led by artist Ruth Catlow, in collaboration with local Youth Empowerment consultant Courtney Hessey that brought together young people aged 19–28 to explore new approaches to increasing their agency to act on sustainability issues through creative storytelling, role-play, radical care methods, and digital media. Based in the coastal town of Felixstowe, the project helped local youth imagine new futures through the eyes of animals and plants, using digital face-filters, animation, photography, and social media to tell their stories.

Working with local youth leaders, this project empowers young people through creating a safe space for engaging with serious topics - for learning, sharing, and fun, while also building real-world skills and confidence. Participants co-designed workshops, made interspecies 'influencer' videos, and co-created a public report to share what they learned. The project helped people feel more connected to nature, their community, and themselves and gave them new ways to speak up about the things they care about. Felixstowe Youth VOICE shows how art can help tackle big issues like environmental justice, biodiversity and climate change in ways that are personal, powerful, and playful. It also offers a model for other towns and youth groups to use in their own communities.
nodes.who_involved: Youth empowerment leads in Felixstowe, and Level Two Youth Project
nodes.legacy_impacts:
The FYV project successfully initiated the discussion on critical eco-social issues prevalent within Felixstowe's young population, including significant inequality, deprivation, and insufficient climate education.
FYV identified the importance of rigorous community-needs mapping, highlighted the necessity for youth-centred interventions that leverage creative and immersive methodologies to facilitate ecological stewardship and civic engagement.
The project has had a profound impact on the nine local young adults due to the robust co-creative framework all the participants (artists, youth co-designers, and extended network, local venues, critical friends) iterated.
Further it has led the foundation for youth leadership development in Felixstowe and the development of participant, FYV and Furtherfield's ongoing strategic programme of work "Reimagine This Coastal Town".
nodes.challenges:
Youth disengagement during holiday period and post-workshop drop-off risked losing momentum.
Limited capacity to influence institutional systems (e.g. education, local policy) within the project timeframe.
Participants had difficulty grappling with the terminology, concepts, and complexity of environmental justice discussions, reflective of public and youth understanding of climate justice.
Ethical tensions around technology use required ongoing reflection and slowed integration of digital tools.
Managing varied expectations and emotional readiness across participants.
Digital Infrastructure / Access: Variable digital fluency and access across participants required additional facilitation effort and workaround strategies.
Emotional labour and affective impacts are challenging for artists' well-being.
nodes.methods:
Mentor Species Reflection and Character Development Process, Interspecies Meditation and Sharing Circle, Live Action Role Play (LARP), Immersive Multispecies Roleplay, Social Holography, Creative Workshop Design, Historical Art Dissemination practices, Media Co-Production

nodes.name: Mammary Mountain
description: An intimate performative VR experience that explores “dis-ease” within the body through the experience of breast cancer. This interactive experience told the stories of patient healthcare struggles, particularly on the hidden experiences of breast cancer treatment. This artwork was presented through a combination of interactive VR art installation and creative methodologies, audiences experienced the stories of survivors, the treatments, and the often unspoken effects of the journey.

This project uses wearable technology, VR, haptics and mobile systems as expressive tools. Actuators that deliver felt experience vibration in different parts of the chest, on each side where the mammary glands and lymph nodes are, and in varied patterns and intensities depending on the scene and story content.
nodes.who_involved: This artwork was created by Tara Baoth Mooney, Camille Baker, Maf’J Alvarez, with sub-contractors Sophie Skach & Paul Hayes. Breast cancer survivors and their families were also key collaborators in the creation of this artwork.
nodes.legacy_impacts: It toured Europe, the UK and the US to immersive and digital arts festivals from December 2023 to August 2025.
nodes.challenges:
It has had trouble accessing healthcare contexts and charities, where women may benefit from experiencing it, especially at the start of their breast cancer journey, to help them understand the possible treatments they face (to reassure them they can get through it), mostly due to red-tape and the healthcare gatekeepers.
Some common issues which arose during this project included:
Technical failure: Technology may fail mid-experience. This can be addressed with testing, clear setup, and fallback systems help.
Emotional triggering: Stories may be too intense. Solutions include: strong trigger warnings, optional exit at any time, debriefing with audience and emotional support on-site.
Community access barriers: Reaching participants is hard, especially when dealing with health-related trauma. It can be useful to reach out through existing networks, charities, and careful outreach to build trust (this can take time!).
Data ethics: Stories are only used with full consent; no sensitive data is stored beyond what's agreed to.
nodes.budget: Baker got £40,000 for project production funds, plus £4000+ from Baker's personal funds and travel funding of £10,000 to participate in the Venice Biennale 2024 Immersive Exhibition = £54,000 (but costs continue to be incurred, covered by Baker as the producer)
nodes.methods:
Workshops with the survivors and their families,
Investigative Story Development,
Experience Design in the development,
User testing of the final piece,
Audience interaction and observation in exhibitions

nodes.name: INTER/her: Journey Inside the Female Body
description: The INTER/her project is an immersive installation and virtual experience. It was created to open up the conversation about phenomena experienced by women in their late 30’s (sometimes earlier) their 40’s, and sometimes after menopause. Working in consultation with a gynaecologist, the project features interviews with a number of women telling their stories. INTER/her has a focus on female reproductive diseases explored through a feminist lens; as personal exploration, as a conversation starter, to raise greater public awareness and encourage community building.
nodes.who_involved: This artwork was created by Camille Baker and Maf’j Alvarez. The community here is mostly women who have suffered from breast cancer treatment and survived, as well as their families and clinicians.
nodes.legacy_impacts: It has toured around the UK and Canada in various arts organiation locations and site-specific spaces (shopping malls, parking gargages, and libraries) from June 2021 to October 2023
nodes.challenges: It has had trouble accessing healthcare contexts where women may benefit from experiencing it, and be more emboldened to self-advocate for earlier diagnosis and treatment - or just to be taken seriously - mostly due to GP's lack of training and understanding of women's reproductive health concerns, NHS red-tape and the healthcare gatekeepersnot recognising the relevance.
nodes.budget: Baker got £15,000 grant funding and put in another £7000 of her own personal funds into the project for travel and exhibitions as well as ongoing tech support.
nodes.methods:
Interaction Design,
Experience Design in the User testing of the final piece,
Audience interaction and observation in exhibitions
