nodes.name: Fixperts
description: Fixperts was initiated by Daniel Charney and partners to provide a programme and platform for connecting students with real people and communities, linking imagination with skills, and ideas with hands-on experimentation. The Fixperts programme has been adopted by educators around the world and various models were developed. More than a thousand Fixperts videos were created to show how co-creation leads to design innovation and empowerment.
nodes.legacy_impacts: Over 50 universities have run the Fixperts programme worldwide, producing hundreds of videos showing how designers work with fix partners (e.g., an individual or a community) to co-create real-world solutions to improve people’s life. The outcome has been exhibited in London, Milan, Shanghai, and Tokyo. Fixperts received multiple awards (e.g., RSA Pupil Design Awards, Sir Misha Black Award for Innovation in Design Education)
nodes.challenges: Having initiated Fixperts projects at Brunel University of London, Tongji University, and Loughborough University, I notice that the challenge is to identify appropriate fix partners to work with, and (for designers) to develop skills in listening and co-creating – these are key to the success of the project.
nodes.budget: Budgets varied, and Fixperts projects can be run with zero budget.
nodes.involved_institutions: Over 50 universities and hundreds and thousands of individuals/communities were involved, including Brunel University (partners included the Hillingdon Library), Tongji University (partners included Neighbourhood communities in Yangpu District), Loughborough University (Partners included a disabled art teacher), and Mimar Sinan Fine Arts University (partners included local disability organisations such as the Six Dots)

nodes.name: CoDesRes
description: CoDesRes was one of six national EPA-funded United Nations Sustainable Development Goals Projects. CoDesRes brings together an interdisciplinary team of artists, scholars, engineers and marine biologists to co-design and co-develop a multi-stakeholder approach for a ‘beyond-compliance’ engagement with the Sustainable Development Goals 4, Education; 11, Sustainable Cities And Communities; 14. Life Below Water and 15, Life On Land.
nodes.who_involved:
Dr Anita McKeown - project concept / methodology and oversight. Also included delivery and PhD supervision; Lucy Hunt, SMARTlab PhD candidate, School of Materials and Mechanical Engineering; Eleanor Turner, SMARTlab PhD candidate, School of Materials and Mechanical Engineering; Rebecca White, James Murphy, Dr Colin Keogh, Rapid Foundation and Séan O'Laoghaire, artist, educator and storytellerCommunity partners - 22 organisations
Direct engagement with 4503 people
nodes.legacy_impacts:
Seven proof of concept  interventions and step-by-step plans for community projects 
 Series of formal and informal education interventions to localise the SDGs 
 Open source SDG resources for educators and communities available at www.codesres.ie/ resources 
 Caherdaniel River Restoration project National and Cultural Heritage Strategy and Implementation plan and pilot project 
 Muinín Catalyst legacy funding to build out and trial the education SDG toolkit - €50K 
 Successful Rural Regeneration Development Fund (RRDF) bid - €200K in partnership with Kerry County Council - to develop 'shovel ready' feasibility for place-based STEAM education and Placemaking Research Development and Innovation centre of excellence in Cahersiveen 
 Development and transfer of the project's circular economic focus and co-design through the EPA funded sister project MARplas €100k; addressing marine plastic waste in coastal communities through innovation and local sustainable enterprise continuing to contribute to six part-time employment positions and additional learning resources 
 RRDF Clár Innovation Fund successful bid €50K  - Include Labs SMARTlab Skelligs 
 Upskilled research team within local context, with economic impact further evidenced through employment positions and new professional collaborations 
 Educational development spin-out company, Future Focus21c - with SMARTlab Skelligs raised €300K for Muinin Catalyst Sustainable STEAM project and created the SME now part of VOICE
nodes.challenges:
Introduction of arts-led regeneration / systemic thinking to rural / coastal community - community activity often linked to GAA (sports) Traditional music
Collaboration in a high context / non-tech literate context is not easy.  The communities' knowledge and connection are not implicit / relational
Local wisdom needed alignment with 21c expertise
School engagement - CPD for 21c pedagogies and inter / muti - literacy development is not high among local educators - but this is also a national / international issue esp. with climate, futures and digital literacies
WP leads were early-stage researchers - learning engaged / embedded and non standard research skills 'on the job'
nodes.budget: Original 165k with raised an additional €359,100 for legacy projects and €41,200 in-kind
nodes.methods: Core methodolgy / methods were pCr and inclusive design for education - proof of concepts developed / iterated 7 new arts-led methods

nodes.name: Trauma Informed Placemaking
description: ‘Trauma-informed placemaking’ is a new praxis conceived by Dr Cara Courage and Dr Anita McKeown. It originated in their observations of the traumatic rupture in the people-place relation during COVID-19 pandemic and the sites of Black Lives Matter protests and police brutality; people were either ‘removed’ from their public realm through lockdown/shelter in place strictures, or the streets they had peacefully inhabited became sites of violent unrest.
nodes.who_involved: It features 66 indigenous, community, artist and practitioner contributors, from 14 countries, across 36 chapters.
nodes.legacy_impacts:
Publication of book offering 20 original frameworks and toolkits related to trauma informed placemaking practices.
Creation of website of resources linked to authors / international projects
Irish Architecture CPD - Reimagine Series of Masterclasses
Irish Architecture pocket guide - trauma informed placemaking
Blog and podcasts linked to chapter's authors
nodes.challenges:
Editing deadlines being balanced with work.
Personal / Professional - many of the authors were working in fast changing traumatic contexts e.g. changes in US policy and practices, civil war, surveillance, civil unrest
Formatting (expression of arts processes within academic formats)
nodes.budget: Self-funded Royalites pays for website and hosting events
nodes.methods: Various / multi-disciplinary insights  - many of the practice chapters are unique methods the artists developed over years of operating in eco-social contexts. The book presents 20 original frameworks, toolkits, and learning exercises, these are signposted and cross-referenced throughout the book.

nodes.name: S+T+ARTS Aqua Motion
description: The S+T+ARTS AQUA MOTION project is set to transform water management in Europe by merging artistic experimentation with cutting-edge technological innovations. Over 24 months, artists will collaborate with researchers, policymakers, businesses, and local communities to develop sustainable, creative solutions for pressing water challenges. The project focuses on four major European water basins—Atlantic-Arctic, Baltic-North Sea, Mediterranean, and Danube-Black Sea—ensuring regionally relevant interventions that align with local needs and broader European objectives. A total of 25 residencies will support artists in developing experimental, technology-driven artistic solutions to water-related challenges. Hosted in four countries, the residencies will facilitate deep engagement with local communities, scientists, and environmental stakeholders to explore creative interventions that promote water sustainability​.
nodes.who_involved: INOVA+ (Portugal) (Coordinator), AIR CENTRE (Portugal), +ATLANTIC CoLAB (Portugal), Rio Neiva (Portugal), WAAG (Netherlands), Hortimare VM (Netherlands), Ars Electronica (Austria), TU Wien (Austria), WAMU-NET (Italy), MUSE (Italy), Pro Progressione (Hungary), KIKK (Belgium)

nodes.name: Water Sensor Module Design
description: A key part of the the RiverSync Project was the design of a Water Sensor Module, moored on a buoy on the River Spree. It's method of creation included the development of a floating, modular sensing device created through a series of participatory workshops and iterative prototyping which all influenced its design. It captures data such as water quality, sound, and video, using Raspberry Pi and environmental sensors. The buoy serves both scientific and poetic functions, bridging physical ecosystems with digital representations.
nodes.steps:
1. Foundation, Ideation, Team Expansion and Onboarding: reach out and welcome team members with required knowledge, such as a programmer and designers, to align academic and technical expertise with the project goals. Begin with collaborative ideation sessions, engaging with practitioners such as artists, programmers, and scientists. Use online visual digital platform tools to support collaborative ideating, such as Miro or Canva, for mapping workflows, milestones, collaborative processes and aligning visions. Collaboratively define ecological and aesthetic goals: framing the project around ecological narratives, considering the Rights of Nature, eco-social storytelling, and more-than-human perspectives. Experiment with Generative Design, using tools such as TouchDesigner to prototype and explore generative water patterns for visualizing data.
2. Workshops and Design Sessions: Initiate the first Design Session to build an inclusive workshop structure, enabling co-creation across disciplines and communities. Host participatory workshops, for example RiverSync hosted TU Berlin and Spore Workshops. Begin with meditations or rituals that centre water as a subject. Plan participatory workshops which include a blend of expert talks, group discussions, and hands-on problem-solving. Integrate diverse perspectives through design workshops - to include river communities, artists, and technologists, using hybrid formats (in-person/digital) for accessibility.
3. Use Workshop Outcomes to Inform Design: collect field notes, then work to cluster themes, and derive actionable goals from the workshop data and analysis. Embed the ideas directly into the sensor planning.
4. Creative Development: sketch UI concepts and physical modules (buoys and sensors), bridging form and function. Refine the 3D buoy prototype to meet artistic, ecological, and practical needs. Initiate a visual interface to communicate water quality data engagingly (here, BadBerlin.Info).
5. Technological Development and Prototyping: Onboard technical collaborators, involving coders and engineers early in the process in order to ensure full integration from the outset. Assign roles based on expertise – such as, from sensor configuration to UI/UX design. Design the Buoy Sensor Module – beginning with sketching by hand, then developing into detailed 3D CAD models, ensuring to emphasize modularity, weatherproofing, and river-specific sustainability. Prototype Data Systems integrating Raspberry Pi, hydrophones, and sensors. Test in controlled settings before deploying in natural environments. Develop UI/UX in Figma, translating concept into visual interface. Focus on accessibility, narrative flow, and live data integration.
6. Iterative Design and Refinement: Use CAD and 3D modelling tools to design and develop the buoy sensor module. Iterate and develop modular systems for data, sound (hydrophones), and video, centred on Raspberry Pi integration based on findings from prototyping stage. Develop a finalised user interface prototype in Figma, based on user-centred design principles.
7. Field Testing: Deploy prototypes in real sites for live prototyping and ongoing testing of sensors and power supply, rapid design iteration, and integration of data/audio/video modules in natural river environments. Refine hardware and UX through live data capture and environmental testing. Prove feasibility of real-time data and media transmission, with attention to resilience in outdoor settings. Develop a housing prototype for sensor and Raspberry Pi systems; and identify further needs in power and weatherproofing. Finalize hardware orders for the production phase.
nodes.challenges:
Interdisciplinary Coordination: Balancing artistic vision with technical feasibility requires constant communication across fields.
Environmental Conditions: Water-based deployments must account for weather, moisture, durability, and access to reliable power sources.
Technical Complexity: Integrating hardware (sensors, Raspberry Pi, audio/video) with software (data visualization, streaming) can be time-intensive and requires iterative testing.
Community Engagement: Ensuring meaningful participation from diverse stakeholders demands sensitivity, accessibility, and sustained outreach.
Scalability and Sustainability: Designing buoy systems that are modular, adaptable, and low-maintenance is essential for long-term impact and reproducibility.
nodes.conditions:
Create a collaborative environment: find an open, interdisciplinary space for artists, technologists, and communities to co-create.
Access to water sites is needed - natural river environments for field testing and ecological connection.
Community Participation is key for the involvement of local or affected communities for contextual relevance - eg. what is most useful to measure with the sensor?
Technical Infrastructure needed includes basic internet access, power sources, and tools for prototyping.
Materials and Tools:
This method makes use of digital tools such as Miro or similar digital whiteboard,TouchDesigner (for generative visuals), Figma (for UI/UX design), Rhino/CAD (for 3D modelling), Python (for sensor integration and data transmission), Raspberry Pi OS – these may require a power supply and SD card.
In addition, hydrophones, environmental sensors (e.g., temperature, turbidity, pH) may be used.
Microphones and camera modules, and Buoy materials (weatherproof casing, floating body, modular casing) may also be required.
Artistic Materials include Sketching tools (pencil, paper, digital tablets). Note-taking and documentation tools (physical notebooks or shared drives).

nodes.name: Forest Walking and AI Storytelling Workshops
description: The Forest Walking and AI Storytelling Method is an immersive, participatory, sound-integrated and reflective artistic approach designed to explore human and more-than-human relationships through walking, listening, and conversational exchange. It centres on ecological awareness, immersive sound, and characters, collaborative dialogue, and the imaginative use of AI to activate forest environments as playful, co-creative spaces for active ecological engagement and reflection.
nodes.steps:
1. Preparation and Scouting: Establish key locations and connections for the workshop: visit the forest site with key collaborators and local contacts. Scout and map the walking route that will be used for the workshop. Identify a nearby venue for the AI session's part of the workshop and technical needs.
2. Stakeholder Mapping and Communication: To understand the ecosystem of human and nonhuman stakeholders, Zone Mapping is used (inspired by Anita McKeown's pCr methodology). Create a zone map to visualise stakeholder relationships (e.g., forest rangers, communities, trees, technologies). Use this map to plan communication strategies in advance of the workshop.
3.Sound Collection and AI Generation: Collaborators here include a sound artist and AI and interaction developer. Record ambient sounds and interviews in situ, within the forest setting. Translate AI-generated scripts and prompts to accommodate local languages (here Dutch).
4. Forest Workshop: This requires 1 preparation day, 5 workshop days, and 1 debrief day.
Forest Walk (Part 1): Using the route mapped during the scouting step, take slow, sensory walking to heighten awareness of the forest environment. Participants are equipped with binaural sound recordings and reflective masks to alter perception and enhance listening.
Conversational Encounters (Part 2): Invite participants to have conversations with AI-generated "forest characters" (e.g., trees, fungi, elements). Offer the option to create their own characters, using accessible chatbot tools. Frame conversations within the speculative context of the Synocene (an imagined future beyond the Anthropocene) to encourage speculative ecological reflections.
5. Debrief, Reflection and Documentation: Host a closing day for feedback, reflection, and data collection, prioritising open dialogue with participants about their experiences. Archive responses, including both verbal and nonverbal reflections. Gather documentation, such as: photos, sound recordings, sketches, maps, transcripts.
6. Post-Workshop Creation and Legacy: Further outputs could include: a video of the workshop experience, a long-form video incorporating workshops across multiple sites, a future sound installation or the installation of sounds in multiple locations accessible for participants, sharing outcomes with contributing communities, and evolving this method in new environments, with new voices.
nodes.challenges:
Scouting: Ensure to note the physical proximity between the walking and workshop spaces – this enhances flow and comfort during the overall workshop. Account for practical limitations (such as stakeholder availability). Schedule the workshop at a time that accommodates local calendars and holidays.
Zone mapping: Make sure to gain ethical engagement and community consent.
Ethical Reflections: Be adaptive and reflexive, considering questions such as:
How is AI being used — as interface or as interaction? Are you inviting reflection or prescribing meaning? How do cultural expectations affect artistic process (e.g., goal-oriented vs exploratory approaches)? What responsibility do you hold in shaping more-than-human voices?
Document emerging ethical questions, considering how translation, tone, and cultural specificity affect engagement.
nodes.conditions:
This method posits artists as problem posers, not problem solvers, so ensure to offer open frameworks, not fixed answers.
The method prioritises collaboration over instruction, working to co-create with participants, AI, and place.
Process is viewed as a priority over product – allow the method evolve from context, encounter, and feedback.
This method is particularly linked to more-than-human awareness, learning to listen to, 'speak with', and design for other-than-human beings.
Here, responsiveness is key in adapting to ethical, cultural, and environmental conditions in real time.
Materials needed: reflective masks, headphones so that each participant can listen in on the walk from their personal device, possibly - depending on the context of the workshop - a few mobile phones/tablets/laptops, wifi (which can be provided via a specific service if the venue is unable to provide it).
publications: Hupont, I., Wainer, M., Nester, S., Tissot, S., Iglesias-Blanco, L. and Baldassarri, S., 2024, May. Synocene, Beyond the Anthropocene: De-Anthropocentralising Human-Nature-AI Interaction. In Extended Abstracts of the CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems (pp. 1-9): https://dl.acm.org/doi/abs/10.1145/3613905.3637118
Benincasa, C. and Eeckels, A., 2025. Could bridging science and the arts be the key to better policies?. Nature, 643(8074), pp.1182-1184: https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-025-02351-x

Mateu, P., 2024. ¿Cómo percibe la Inteligencia Artificial la naturaleza? Este proyecto científico-artístico trata de descubrirlo. National Geographic Espana: https://www.nationalgeographic.com.es/ciencia/como-percibe-inteligencia-artificial-naturaleza-este-proyecto-cientifico-artistico-trata-descubrirlo_23156

Bianchi, G., Matti, C., Pontikakis, D., Reimeris, R., Haegeman, K.H., Miedzinski, M., SILLERO, I.C., Mifsud, S., Sasso, S., Bol, E. and MARQUES, S.A., 2024. Innovation for place-based transformations: ACTIONbook, practices and tools section, page C8: https://publications.jrc.ec.europa.eu/repository/handle/JRC135826
nodes.templates:
The AI interface was developed with OpenAI API (Application Programming Interface) gpt3.5-turbo-instruct-0914 version. This version allowed a better integration of the Dutch translation.
Dutch Interface: https://sandbox.data.bingo/synoceneGPTNL/
Note: The fifth chatbot was not pre-defined; workshop participants were invited to create their own forest character. The character that appears is the last one created by a workshop participant.

nodes.name: Biomaterial Workshops
description: The Biomaterial Workshop Method iterative, generative method - that builds upon each other - using recycled lab and medical materials to create art-based workshops that invite participants into hands-on making, reflective discussion and playful exploration. It blends wet and dry felting, biomaterial crafting, and facilitated conversation to provoke new ways of seeing waste, contamination, care, and reuse in clinical and research settings. Participants range from scientists and patients, to artists and hospital staff, and are guided through accessible, tactile activities that generate community dialogue and creative experimentation.
nodes.steps:
1. Preparation, Planning and Materials: Choose an accessible venue or platform appropriate to your participants ensuring it is an inviting space (e.g. a local community centre, hospital seminar room, museum, gallery studio or online platform). Source and gather safe waste and surplus materials and tools required, potentially via collaborators or partners — for example, wool waste (from lab glassware packaging), bio-digested hospital aprons, agar, synthetic bodily fluids (fake blood, phlegm), UV sterilisation research materials. Prepare a short, informal introduction covering your artistic concept, inspiration (e.g. the bacterial sublime), and workshop itinerary and expectations. Consider and invite participants to form mixed groups (such as scientists, artists, patients, healthcare professionals), and tailor workshop framing to match. Ensure to gain written permission and ethical consent from participants prior to workshops, for their participation, and use of any imagery, photographs, videos, or quotes.
2. Workshop Structure: Consider the workshop structure – workshops are modular and can be adapted to different materials or contexts. Setup and display examples of sample biomaterials or artworks to create context and invite discussion. Follow the example workshop structure:
A. Welcome, Framing and Opening Talk: Introduce your artistic practice and themes via a short presentation. Frame provocations: What is waste? What is contamination? What is beauty or usefulness? Provide context and introduce themes around contamination, aesthetics, and material reuse. Encourage curiosity and freedom rather than perfection.
B. Hands-On Making and Experimentation: (In-Person): Introduce (for example) wool waste and other biomaterials for experimental felting and manipulation, such as bio-digested apron compost and wool felting. Invite participants to use techniques such as wet felting or needle felting, and to create bioplastics and biocomposites: to feel, mix and create, whilst facilitating discussions (see C). Encourage participants to combine textures, colours, and states (e.g. "dirty" vs "clean") and explore transformations. (Online): Post materials ahead of time (if feasible). Use wool felting via video conferencing software, with discussion prompts throughout.
C. Collective Discussion, Co-Reflection and Group Dialogue: "As the hands are occupied, the mind is free to wander and chat" - use artistic making to prompt discussion and facilitate open dialogue around sustainability in labs and perceptions of contamination. Encourage conversation about sustainability practices in personal and institutional contexts. Raise relevant contextual questions, as per the project and audience, such as: Why are some materials rejected despite being sterile or safe? How does shifting scientific advice affect public trust? How do we react aesthetically or culturally to visible mess? In online settings, ensure to maintain a strong presence and responsive facilitation.
D. Optional: You could include a Speculative Experiment: Inviting participants to create pieces, exploring the concept of 'visibly soiled' using synthetic materials (such as synthetic blood or phlegm). Include optional speculative design actions (for example, sterilising 'messy' art with UV light). Allow time to reflect on contradictions and transformations.
E. Closing the Session: Offer time for reflection: written or spoken - encourage sharing of ideas, thoughts, discomforts, insights. Ask participants what they might do differently in their own work or institutions and invite feedback for iterative learning.
3. Post-Workshop Development: Compile feedback and transcripts, using the findings to: refine future workshop formats, generate new artworks or installations, and engage stakeholders across sectors (for example, hospital sustainability leads, and university labs). Consider public outcomes, such as a film, sound piece, or zine capturing the material and ethical tensions.
nodes.challenges:
Scientific scepticism or confusion: Some participants may find interdisciplinary conversations challenging.
Cultural attitudes toward contamination: The concept of 'visibly soiled' can be provocative so ensure to use care when exploring discomfort.
Ethical limits of material use: Sourcing biomaterial demands transparency and sensitivity.
Power dynamics: Flatten hierarchies gently but firmly, aiming to empower all voices in the room.
More-than-human awareness: Acknowledge the presence and ethics of organic waste, bacteria, and living processes.
Storage and disposal: Be mindful of how bio-waste is handled, before and after the workshop.
nodes.conditions:
Framing Practice and Approach: Embrace a non-hierarchical, participatory process that centres community input, experimentation, and open-ended outcomes.
This entails creating a supportive and exploratory space fostering serious play, shared learning and critical dialogue.
This structure allows for a mix of aspects of theory, practice and reflection.
Positioning and Environment: Foster a friendly, supportive atmosphere with refreshments - offering food and comfort if in-person; or creating space for informal exchange if using online settings.
nodes.templates:
Website: https://annadumitriu.co.uk/portfolio/better-factory-iowa/
Dropbox Link For Biomaterials Recipe Book: https://www.dropbox.com/scl/fi/grn18ta1ylew0ecsxqhxk/Biomaterials-Recipe-Book.pdf?rlkey=fzs4pjt7s4iyeevx8m2bx6j98&e=1&dl=0

nodes.name: Repair and Reuse Textile Workshops
description: The Repair and Reuse Textile Sampling Workshop Method is a creative, collaborative workshop approach focused on transforming textile waste—offcuts, scraps, and discarded garments—into new forms through accessible upcycling techniques. It uses fashion aesthetics, cooperative making, and hands-on learning to empower participants with both technical skills and imaginative confidence.
This method can be adapted for varied group settings and is ideal for community studios, fashion schools, and arts-led sustainability initiatives.
nodes.steps:
1. Prepare Your Materials and Setting: Gather offcuts, fabric scraps, and unwanted garments (such as, an old pair of jeans). Bring basic sewing equipment: scissors, pins, needles, sewing machines. Have a sample garment on hand to act as a design template (for example, a maxi skirt). Prepare a demonstration (for example, the 'strip foundation piecing' technique - a method where fabric strips are sewn onto a base cloth, building a patchwork surface). If available, bring digital or printed visuals to support visual learning.
2. Introduce the Concept and Technique: Begin with a short talk, which could: explain the goals of upcycling; introduce specific techniques (such as strip foundation piecing, yarn made from t-shirts or Reverse appliqué); show the sample garment; and discuss possible transformations. This method is guided by fashion thinking - encouraging experimentation while also aiming for a wearable or functional outcome.
3. Engage in Cooperative Making: Divide participants into small working groups or pairs and begin by constructing small test pieces (such as, using strip foundation piecing). Focus on composition, colour play, and stitch experimentation. Use these sample pieces as templates for scaling up. Transition into a shared transformation task (for example, converting jeans into a skirt). Encourage participants to talk through their process - narrating their decisions, explaining the challenges, and suggesting solutions collaboratively.
4. Support Creative Decision-Making: Provide encouragement and technical input as needed (for aspects such as garment structure, stitch techniques). Reinforce that experimentation and play are valued, and allow participants to modify the process as they respond to the materials.
5. Document the Process: Film short clips of the participants working showing 'hands-in-action', voiceovers, or group discussions ensuring to gain ethical consent to do so. Capture both finished outcomes and in-progress moments. Discuss how video and sound clips could be used to share techniques and reach broader audiences (through social media, zines, installations).
6. Reflect and Share: At the end of the workshops, hold short group reflection sessions asking: What worked and what was more challenging? What would you try next time? How do you feel about the materials you used? Highlight the potential for showcasing outcomes, such as at fashion shows or community exhibitions. Link the discussions to circular fashion narratives, using the workshop as a space to discuss themes of repair culture, mending heritage, and care ethics in fashion.
nodes.challenges:
Repair and upcycling are both technical skills and creative mindsets – this means that it is important to intertwine making with sustainability discussions and reflections. Participants often need structured guidance to get started – but once this initial support is provided, it is observed that many participants flourish when given the freedom to experiment and play.
Collaborative working helps participants to demystify textile processes or garment construction and fosters peer learning – it may function differently if working with participants on an individual basis.
Documenting the processes through media can democratise access to knowledge and inspire others - do ensure to gain ethical consent for use (for example) photography, video, written and spoken feedback from participants.
If participants are struggling to visualise the end result of a repair technique - guide them to work in different ways such as using sketching, draping, or pinning ideas onto mannequins or hangers.
Technology-assisted learning may be considered, such as the use of QR codes linking to video demonstrations, or audio guides or podcasts for sewing tips and techniques.
nodes.conditions:
Workshop Space and Equipment: Finding and fostering a collaborative environment is helpful in order to encourage a supportive, inclusive space for discussion and shared making.
Basic workshop setup and sewing equipment is required including: tables, chairs, good lighting, and access to power for sewing machines, access to basic sewing tools including scissors, pins, needles, thread, measuring tape, seam rippers. Access to sewing machines (at least one per 3-4 participants).
A minimum time of 2-3 hours works well to give space for sampling and collaborative making.
Facilitator guidance is required, from someone with knowledge of repair processes, garment construction and textile techniques.
Ensure to allow space for reflection (dialogue) and display (of sample), which could be wall or table space, to share sample pieces and progress.
Materials required include: Fabric offcuts, scraps, and remnants, old garments (such as jeans or shirts for transformation), base cloth for repair techniques (lightweight cotton or muslin), garment templates or sample pieces (such as a maxi skirt for reference).
Optional extras could be added, depending on which repair techniques are being used, including t-shirts (for yarn-making), additional embellishment materials (buttons, trims, patches), as well as audio and video equipment for documenting the process.
nodes.publications:
Hernandez, L., Petreca, B., Baurley, S., Bianchi-Berthouze, N. and Cho, Y., 2024. Examining clothing repair practices, core competences, techniques, tools and community structures involved in extending the life of garments. International Journal of Sustainable Fashion & Textiles, 3(1), pp.99-121: https://discovery.ucl.ac.uk/id/eprint/10194714/
Ealing Repair Cafe Short Film: https://touchcraft.org.uk/ealing-repair-cafe-short-film/

nodes.name: Community Mapping and Social Media
description: The Community Mapping and Social Media method combines analogue and digital mapping, observational research and brainstorming techniques to reveal complex organisational structures and identify opportunities for design interventions. It is a design research method that can highlight the values and dynamics of an organisation, uncover its setup and their priorities for future actions. In addition, it can support community visibility, skill-sharing, and sustainability by documenting and sharing stories through online platforms like Instagram.
nodes.steps:
1. Observe and Document Community Practices: Ensure to gain written ethical consent from the community prior to meeting or observation. Then, once consent is obtained, ask to participate in or attend repair/upcycling workshops or community gatherings. Take observational notes on group dynamics, learning styles, decision-making, and collaborative making processes. Record video and audio clips (with permission) to capture key interactions and techniques in real-time.
2. Brainstorm with the Group: Host a face-to-face meeting and facilitate the group to brainstorm issues around the community setup. Use this opportunity to collect more detail about how the community structures itself and map its partners, resources, venues, challenges, successes, goals and future plans. Give the group pens, paper and post-it notes to write the information for themselves. Ask the community directly to identify other areas that may be missing or need further clarity such as what people do, how they do it, and why it matters.
3. Create a Digital Community Map: Use a digital tool (like Miro) to depict the key issues identified in the previous step such as activities, values, and interactions. Identify key themes within the mapping, such as improvised learning, peer decision-making, and interpersonal communication.  Share and reflect on the mapping with the community to ensure it reflects their perspectives, feedback and values. This visualisation helps clarify the unique cultural and educational values of the community's work.
4. Edit and Curate Media Content: Use digital editing software to select meaningful clips that represent: the character of the group, key making processes and examples of learning or collaboration. Add captions, context, or music if appropriate, for accessibility and engagement.
5. Set Up a Community Instagram or Social Media Page: Create a dedicated Instagram account, adding a biography that explains the group's purpose and invites participation. Upload a profile photo and a few starter posts in order to set the tone of the group and page.
6. Share Stories and Engage New Audiences: Regularly post short videos, photos, or quotes from your mapped content. Focus on accessible, inspiring, and human-centred content that highlights repair culture. Use hashtags, tags, and location features to expand visibility and reach younger or local audiences.
7. Support Sustainable Growth: Discuss social media management with the community: who will post, how often, and with what tone. Consider developing a content calendar or offering training to participants who want to co-manage the account. Link Instagram content to other creative outputs like films, exhibitions, or events to maintain relevance and impact.
nodes.challenges:
Privacy and consent: Always get written ethical consent and clear permission to film and share images or quotes.
Transparency: Collaborate with the group to ensure the maps reflect the key issues and values reported by them.
Sustaining momentum: Maintaining an active social media presence requires time, care, and consistency.
Balancing authenticity and curation: Ensure that posts reflect real community values, not just polished highlights.
It is important to ensure the community collaborates and that their voice is reflected accurately, and that they consent to the posts and information being shared.

nodes.name: Mentor Species
description: This method is designed to support participants in developing deepened awareness, empathy, and ethical reflection through the creation of more-than-human characters, called specifically ‘Mentor Species’. It helps participants explore interspecies relationships, challenge anthropocentric perspectives, and prepare for collaborative roleplay exercises. The process invites ethical imagination, emotional engagement, and ecological thinking, and prepares participants for roleplay exercises and games.
nodes.steps:
1. Preparation and Participant Recruitment: Circulate a Call for Participants (CFP) via networks, social media, and community partners – ensuring to use clear, inclusive language. Clarify the workshop intentions in all outreach, explaining that this is an opportunity for collaborative reflection and creative practice, and not a performative acting workshop. Prepare a Character Development Sheet or workbook, which should include reflective prompts, simple guidance, and space for drawing or writing.
2. Scaffolding and Introducing the Concept of the Mentor Species: Begin the session with a gentle introduction to the 'Mentor Species' idea, discussing non-human beings who offer perspective on ecological, ethical, or emotional realities. Emphasise that these species may be: stressed or sick (due to climate, political, or systemic crises); resilient, adaptive, or vulnerable; engaged in complex relationships such as mutualist, competitive, parasitic, or cooperative, with both humans and other species.
3. Reflective Character Building: invite participants to choose or be assigned a species (non-human animal, plant, or even microbe). Use guided prompts to reflect on questions, such as: How is this species doing right now? What might be causing stress or thriving? What does it feel like in their body or environment? What do they know that humans might not? What are their relationships to other life forms (including humans)? Here, try to avoid anthropomorphism unless intentionally used to provoke reflection. Instead, encourage imaginative empathy rooted in ecology.
4. Introduce Ethical and Political Dimensions: encourage participants to consider the following reflections as prompts - how their species' experience intersects with human systems (e.g., capitalism, colonialism, extractivism); what their species might say about justice, care, or responsibility; how this perspective changes their own understanding of the Earth crisis. You might want to reference thinkers such as Robin Wall Kimmerer (traditional and scientific knowledges), Donaldson and Kymlicka (around animal rights and interspecies justice), and Maria Puig de la Bellacasa (environmental ethics and matters of care).
5. Support Roleplay Preparation: ensure to help participants develop the character's voice, considering - how do they speak, move, and express themselves? Explore how the species interacts with others, including potential conflict, solidarity, misunderstanding or curiosity. Begin gentle, low-pressure exercises to embody or represent their species in group contexts.
6. Facilitate Dialogue, Reflections and Mutual Learning: allow time for participants to share their character reflections in pairs or small groups. Use this moment to shift from individual insight to collective understanding, asking critical questions such as: what do we learn from each other's species? How might their relationships mirror or critique human systems?
nodes.challenges:
Accessibility: Ensure the material remains understandable and emotionally safe for all, while still encouraging deep reflection.
Inclusivity: Design prompts and processes that work across neurodivergence, language levels, and lived experience.
Avoid Simplistic Solutions: This method is not about 'fixing' the planet through human action alone but about extending a sense of possibly relations, and reframing how we relate to other beings.
nodes.templates:
Meet the Mentor Species Playing Cards: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1J8-PsFIIL4k6ohIAOzj4b35kguw2Lbnv/view?usp=sharing
Interspecies Character Development sheet: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1s1TU6a4JFJVUIfSWBjTKbMB2MrLNwvIi/view?usp=sharing

nodes.name: Interspecies Meditation and Sharing Circle
description: This method combines guided meditation and roleplay-based sharing to help participants develop empathy for non-human life forms (here, 'mentor species') while exploring systemic environmental issues. Grounded in somatic and imaginative practice, the method creates space to reflect on grief, justice, and co-existence in the Earth Crisis (Bridget McKenzie).

The process encourages cross-species listening and collaborative meaning-making, building emotional literacy alongside ecological awareness. It is especially effective when used in intergenerational or youth-centred spaces exploring biodiversity, planetary boundaries, or multispecies justice.
nodes.steps:
1. Set the Frame (10–15 mins):
Introduce the method clearly and gently, framing it as an imaginative, reflective exercise, not a performance or test. Discuss how participants will be inhabiting the perspective of a non-human 'mentor species' and explain how the purpose is to shift focus from human-centred solutions to relational awareness, grief, and justice.
Share ground rules: These include ensuring respect for different comfort levels, mindful movement (participants may move during the meditation if needed) and emphasising confidentiality and consent in the sharing circle.
Introduce Bridget McKenzie's Earth Crisis diagrams or key concepts (for example, planetary boundaries, societal causes, impacts on lives, tactics and solutions) to give participants a systemic lens for what they may encounter or feel.
2. Guided Interspecies Meditation (10–20 mins, adaptable):
Choose one of two formats depending on your group's needs:
Option A: Traditional Format (Single Flow)
Lead a 20-minute guided meditation helping participants gradually become immersed in their mentor species' world. Begin with somatic grounding (breath, weight, posture). Guide attention into the species' body, senses, landscape. Explore how the species moves, eats, communicates, and interacts. Transition to exploring pressures, stressors, or conflicts the species might face.
Option B: Adapted Format (Segmented for Neurodivergence)
Break the meditation into 3–5 minute segments with short pauses between for mini-reflection or gentle movement. Encourage participants to stand, move, or stim in quiet ways, if needed. After each segment, invite 1–2 words or gestures to reflect what they are noticing. Here, participants can be paired with pre-assigned species based on local ecologies, or allow them to choose species that resonate.
3. Sharing Circle (20–30 mins):
After the meditation, invite participants to speak in character as their mentor species.
Prompt questions include: What comes up for you? What feelings and thoughts? What have you learned? What kind of world would support your thriving? How do you feel about human activity or decisions? Encourage participants to listen and respond as their species, developing a shared web of interspecies dialogue.
4. Collective Reflection and Closure (15–20 mins):
Encourage participants to shift back to speaking as themselves. Prompt reflections including: What surprised you? Did anything shift in how you see your own role in Earth's crisis? Where do you feel grief? Where do you feel responsibility or hope? Offer participants the chance to write or sketch short responses before verbal discussion, especially for those who process internally. Close with a brief grounding or transition ritual (such as - breath, gesture, shared silence, or nature object offering).
nodes.challenges:
Justice for All Species: This method is not about escapism, but about extending a sense of possible relations, redistributing attention, making space for voices excluded from dominant narratives.
Neurodiversity-Informed: Long meditations may be inaccessible for many; build in rest, pacing, and optional ways to participate.
Emotional Terrain: Different feelings are likely to emerge depending on participants' personal experience. In addition to wonder and delight, grief, disappointment and despair may to emerge. Hold space for difficult feelings and avoid rushing toward solutions.
Facilitator Role: Your presence, tone, and responsiveness are crucial. This work needs humility, emotional intelligence, and adaptability.
Technology Caution: Be mindful of technology (for example, face filters or AI tools that may come with their own eco-social justice impacts); prioritise embodied, relational, and human-centred approaches first.
nodes.templates:
Felixstowe Youth VOICE Interspecies Meditation and Sharing Circle Script  (Segmented for Neurodivergence): https://drive.google.com/file/d/1U9z_PPXCMKIXGWMQCf7khv__6qxxS3QI/view?usp=sharing
Interspecies Meditation and Sharing Circle audio download: https://soundcloud.com/interspecies-assemblies/interspecies-meditation-and-sharing-circle

nodes.name: Interaction and Experience Design
description: Interaction and experience design processes are used to create a participatory, performative and immersive practice, this method combines physical interaction, storytelling, haptics and emotional engagement.

This method intersects digital art, performance, immersive storytelling, feminist healthcare activism, interaction design and VR technology. It also draws from theater, sound design, and embodied practices.
This method uses wearable technology, VR, haptics and mobile systems as expressive tools.

Actuators that deliver felt experience of vibration in different parts of the lower abdomen over where the reproductive health concern would take place inside the body (cervix, womb, fallopain tubes, ovaries, etc) and in specific patterns and intensities triggered by story content.
nodes.steps:
1. Topic selection and funding: start with a strong story-driven concept, ideally rooted in social or personal urgency. Funding applications are part of this phase.
2. Community outreach: engage those with lived experience. Often this involves interviews, workshops and forming ethical relationships.
3. Consent and data gathering: record stories with clear consent protocols. Stories become the material, not traditional 'data'.
4. Team assembly: includes creative technologists, sound designers, set designers, animators, etc. Whoever might be needed for your project execution.
5. Interaction and experience design: map out what the audience will see, feel and hear.
6. Prototype and audience testing especially with wearable elements and haptics with critical friends and typlical audience members
7. Build and deploy: design the immersive environment. Calibrate physical setup, headset, haptic feedback, etc.
8. Plan transitions (onboarding/offboarding), emotional pacing, and tactile/ haptic engagement.
9. Exhibition and caretaking: carefully manage audience onboarding and offboarding, including emotional debriefing and support for triggered responses.
nodes.challenges:
Some common issues when using this method include:
Technical failure: Technology may fail mid-experience. This can be addressed with testing, clear setup, and fallback systems help.
Emotional triggering: Stories may be too intense. Solutions include: strong trigger warnings, optional exit at any time, debriefing with audience and emotional support on-site.
Community access barriers: Reaching participants is hard, especially when dealing with health-related trauma. It can be useful to reach out through existing networks, charities, and careful outreach to build trust (this can take time!).
Data ethics: Stories are only used with full consent; no sensitive data is stored beyond what's agreed to.
nodes.conditions:
It requires extensive planning around story development, tech integration (e.g., haptics, VR), ethical considerations, community collaboration, and emotional safety protocols. Camille emphasises mapping emotional intentions at every stage. These are the areas to take into consideration during preparation:
Story development
Tech and haptic integration
Community engagement and ethics
Emotional risk-mapping
Spatial and sensory design
Assembling the right collaborators
The preparation is as much about emotional design as it is about technical execution.

Available online at https://www.bstjournal.com/article/id/9724/

nodes.name: Inclusive Design
description: Inclusive Design is a philosophy, movement and methodology that aims to centre those traditionally excluded from design and cultural processes. As defined by the Inclusive Design Research Centre (http://idrc.ocadu.ca/),inclusive design is, “design that considers the full range of human diversity with respect to ability, language, culture, gender, age and other forms of human difference”. It is an approach used by designers, artists, community workers, researchers, educators, and practitioners who want to engage with diverse perspectives to produce artworks, products, or outcomes that are usable by and respectful of the people they aim to serve. Inclusive Design is an approach rather than one specific tool or method. As a foundational approach within the VOICE project, we have gathered multiple tools and methods used within Inclusive Design processes. Many of these methods are adaptable across disciplines and can be scaled depending on context, budget, or stage of project development. For example, Unlearning & Questioning (UQ),  a method for recognising and dismantling internal biases, and Who’s at the Table? / Virtuous Tornado,  a framework for rethinking inclusion and stakeholder presence throughout an artistic or technological process.
nodes.challenges:
Some common pitfalls associated with this method include:
1. Confusing Inclusive Design with Universal Design: Universal Design assumes a 'universal' user and flattens difference. Inclusive Design starts from the edges and prioritizes personalization. Mistaking the two can lead to well-meaning but exclusionary design.
2. Tokenism: Inviting people in without centering their perspective can create a superficial sense of inclusion. Tools like 'Who's at the Table?'  guard against this by focusing on power and presence.
3. Unacknowledged Subjectivity: Artists often view their practice as open to interpretation, but Inclusive Design reminds us that our own perspective is also subjective and can benefit from reflection and recalibration.
4. Unclear ownership: Failing to clarify contributions, authorship and ownership can cause issues later. It is crucial to agree early on how participants will be credited and acknowledged.
5. Excessive data: Workshops can often yield more data than teams can handle. Even within artistic projects it's important to plan for data management and, where possible, design for future reuse of anonymized material.
nodes.conditions:
In preparing to use Inclusive Design within your work it is important to:
 Be open to self-reflection and discomfort
 Plan how insights gained from activities might influence the project's structure, presentation, and legacy
 Research your participants (needs, contexts, preferences)
 Plan inclusive formats for engagement - think about your participants needs and the project's needs when deciding which tools and methods to use
 Prepare materials that are rough enough to invite interaction, overly polished tools can intimidate participants
 Create time for trust-building, onboarding, and clear communication of purpose and expectations
 Plan for consent and data handling, especially if feedback will be reused
nodes.publications:
Inclusive Design Research Centre: https://idrc.ocadu.ca/
Teaching Inclusive Design: A Toolkit: https://www.responsiblefuturedesigners.com/resources/diam-donec-adipiscing-risus/
M. Moisen (2025), Designing for Everyone: The imperative of Inclusive AI: https://medium.com/@moisenm/designing-for-everyone-the-imperative-of-inclusive-ai-in-the-era-of-gpt-51e82d32276c

nodes.name: Unlearning & Questioning
description: A method to be used as part of an Inclusive Design process, designed to examine and unlearn individual, institutional, and societal assumptions and conventions that block designing for human diversity, variability, and equity and global complexity. Closely connected with the method 'Unlearning and Unsettling'.
nodes.steps:
1. Acknowledge your own position, background, and assumptions.
2. Engage in structured reflection exercises to surface unconscious bias.
3. Question how these biases influence your art, audience, and methods.
4. Adjust or reframe your creative decisions to allow more equitable access and relevance.
5. Repeat this process iteratively, reflection is ongoing, not one-time.
nodes.publications:
Unlearning and Unsettling: Questioning and Reflecting (Module 1 as part of Learning to be Human Together, An online course co-designed by Students, Faculty and Staff at OCAD University, Mohawk College, Brock University, Trent University, Nipissing University, University of Windsor, University of Toronto-Mississauga)
https://ecampusontario.pressbooks.pub/onhumanlearn/chapter/module-1-unlearning-and-unsettling-questioning-and-reflecting/
Treviranus, Jutta (2018) If you want the best design, ask strangers to help. The Medium. Available at: https://medium.com/@jutta.trevira/if-you-want-the-best-design-ask-strangers-to-help-e37bdb73567

nodes.name: Who’s at the Table? / Virtuous Tornado
description: A collaborative and speculative tool to explore representation, power and inclusion. It is designed to help us rethink inclusion and stakeholder presence throughout an artistic, design or technological process. This method is centred around these questions:
Who are we designing with?
Who couldn't access this process or space?
How do we build a project where their voice is central, not peripheral?
nodes.steps:
1. Map out who is currently involved in your project.
2. Ask: 'Who is missing?', 'Why are they missing?'
3. Use speculative personas or communities to rethink access and voice.
4. Imagine the project from these perspectives, what changes?
5. Revise, re-engage, and re-centre those previously excluded.
nodes.conditions: Preparing personas or scenarios for this methodology can take time and requires research. It is important that personas are based on real-life examples. Consider what information you'll need for each 'persona' and how you will find this information.
nodes.publications: Zhang, B., Robb, N., Eyerman, J., & Goodman, L. (2017). Virtual worlds and gamification to increase integration of international students in higher education: an inclusive design approach. International Journal of E-Learning & Distance Education Revue Internationale Du E-Learning Et La Formation à Distance, 32(2). Retrieved from https://ijede.ca/index.php/jde/article/view/1057

nodes.name: Critical User Forums
description: Workshops, forums and design sessions involving direct interaction between design teams and a mixed group of users with severe disabilities. Typical forums consist of roughly 4 - 7 people with different disabilities. Over the course of the session a range of scenarios are explored to assist with the design and development of the artwork, product and/or output.
nodes.steps:
1. Recognise exclusion (who are excluded, and why)
2. Identify critical users you intend to reach to gain insights for inclusion and innovation
3. Hosting a forum with key critical users. In these sessions you'll co-create solutions to improve inclusivity (e.g. a participatory process, and a more inclusive intervention)
4. Reflection  (e.g. on the early decision, the process, and the outcome, what can be learned, and what can be improved)
5. Revise, re-engage, and re-centre those previously excluded.
nodes.challenges:
Difficulties in identifying critical users.
Lack of time and space given to reflection
nodes.conditions: Understanding of who 'critical users' might be and how best to work with them.
nodes.publications: Dong, H., & Cassim, J. (2007). Critical User Forums for Inclusive Design. Ergonomics in Design, 15(4), 4-30. https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.1518/106480407X255233

nodes.name: Empathy Toolkit
description: A tool used within Inclusive Design to support awareness building and testing out new ideas, productions or artworks. The Empathy Toolkit offers a structured way to simulate physical or sensory limitations to better understand others’ experiences.
nodes.steps:
1. Use materials (e.g. gloves, goggles, tape, straps) to simulate specific impairments.
2. Perform a range of everyday tasks with these constraints.
3. Reflect and document your reactions (journaling, sketching, etc.).
4. Use these insights to ideate design adaptations or provocations.
5. Supplement this method with engagement with people who have lived experience (to avoid assumptions).

* Note - Empathy simulation is not a replacement for working with real users, it's a starting point for building awareness and sensitivity.
nodes.challenges:
Some challenges which may arise include:
Misguided empathy: Participants may become patronizing or rush to conclusions without deeply listening. It's important to build relationships slowly and center co-creation throughout.
Overdominant participants: In co-creation, louder voices can drown out others. When delivering these workshops make sure to moderate actively, observe body language, and use checklists to track whose input is being represented.

nodes.name: More-than-human attunement
description: A way for designers and artists to engage with other species, shifting how we understand, relate to, and design with them. It connects more-than-human design with interdisciplinary and transdisciplinary practices, especially between life sciences and creative fields, like biodesign and bioart. It's especially useful for those who want to move beyond treating other species as objects and instead recognize them as subjects with their own agency.

It cultivates empathy, sensory awareness, and the ability to engage with complexity. While we can't fully know what another species wants, careful observation can help us attune to their presence, impact, and needs. It reminds us that we're always in relation, with microbes, plants, animals, even when we don't realize it.
nodes.steps:
1. Shift into active sensing : Slow down and become present.
2. Engage all senses: Touch, smell, hear, observe. Move beyond measurement tools.
3. Practice multispecies observation – Notice what species are present, how they interact.
4. Use creative techniques like:
- Mapping: trace origins, politics, ecologies, and power dynamics of objects/species.
- Journaling: reflect and record lived experience.
- Sound/Photo/Video: document multisensory impressions.
- Material sampling: interact physically with the object or species—don't just research it online.
5. Recognize shifts: Pay attention to changes, growth, or new relationships forming.
6. Allow for wonder:  Let surprise guide new questions and insights.
nodes.challenges:
One major risk is assuming you know what another species wants. You're always interpreting from your own perspective, so it's essential to remain cautious and humble.
Another important critique is that more-than-human methodologies can overlook human injustice. When people are still suffering, due to poverty or exclusion, it raises the ethical question: how do we care for non-humans while so many humans remain uncared for? This method must always exist within a broader context of justice and responsibility.
This approach isn't meant to stand alone. It's a small, valuable addition to existing methodologies, especially ethnographic and ecological ones, and can enrich them by inviting in more-than-human perspectives.
nodes.conditions: The key is learning to speak the community’s language, especially when working with scientists. That means understanding the basics of their scientific framework so you can communicate clearly and respectfully. Once that connection is made, you can open more sensory and emotional channels, bringing in time-lapse videos, personal observations, or embodied experiences to complement the data. This creates space for deeper dialogue and shared insight.

nodes.name: The PermaCultural Resilience praxis
description: The pCr praxis is a framework and toolkit inspired by and borrowing from permaculture methodology. It is a structured, holistic approach to eco-social arts practice and creative placemaking (working with communities to shape the places where they live). It focuses on collaboration, where artists work closely with local people, and it puts fairness, sustainability, and care for both people and the environment at the heart of the process.

Think of it like an "open-source operating system" for arts-led community projects: it provides tools and methods that any artist or other person can use, adapt, and share. The aim is to bring together three key areas: social wellbeing, environmental health, and economic strength — so that communities can build more resilient, healthy, and balanced local systems that support both people and nature.
nodes.steps:
1. Relationships: Stakeholder consultation of partners and audiences carried out within the two-day design sprint at the beginning of the project with all partners. This uses the pCr OBREDIM Audit survey tool - a complexity mapping tool – to identify and track the relationships and actors over time. This will be used to map the existing ecosystem and develop the project and expand the initial theory of change once artists and communities are on board.
2. Zoning: the pCr zoning process maps the information from the stakeholder in proximity to the project and will develop the initial signposts to extend the ecosystem.
3. The Vital Signs Matrix (VSM) Life Cycle Analysis (LCA): the pCr LCA maps the inputs, processes and outputs of the individual projects and the overall programme; this will be used to ascertain the sustainability and insure an eco-social approach to the project.
4. Final Evaluation using the Vital Signs Matrix (VSM): the VSM identifies the health and efficacy of a project's vital signs across 12 indices that embeds social, environmental, and economic justice in its processes. It maps the ambition, outputs and outcomes, and is undertaken at the beginning of the project and will be updated at quarterly intervals to track progress against the Theory of Change to capture emerging impact and behaviour change.
nodes.challenges:
pCr is a whole system approach. It can be used as such or used method by method, yet the over arching ethos is grounded in complexity. Online training can mitigate some aspects of this but really a mentoring situation over a few sessions + later check-ins is most supportive.
Current Mindset 1: Eco-Social, Climate, sustainability and futures literacy is a spectrum of understanding and not common practice despite artists, policies and institutions rhetoric
The understanding and practice of integrated literacies, sustainability, climate and collaborative healthy / vital practices is low. Many organisations / practices are within the ambition of the Brundlant Report's 1987 definition of sustainability, which is almost 40 years old and completely out of date.
nodes.publications:
CoDesRes report(https://www.epa.ie/publications/research/socio-economics/Research_Report_409.pdf) and supporting appendix (https://www.futurefocus21c.com/_files/ugd/92a067_e61bb1c853074097bda23e81a0eb55b5.pdf)
Research Highlights short video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UF9RlOn_lLE&t=8s
Handbook of Placemaking(https://www.routledge.com/The-Routledge-Handbook-of-Placemaking/Courage-Borrup-RosarioJackson-Legge-Mckeown-Platt-Schupbach/p/book/9780367684099) - sub-editor section
Part 5: Placemaking, Environment and Sustaining Ecologies

nodes.name: Waag Futurelab
bio: Waag was established in 1994 by Marleen Stikker and Caroline Nevejan, emerging from the groundbreaking 'De Digitale Stad' (the digital city), an early internet access point and social media hub. Stikker led the charge in pioneering the digital public sphere, chronicling its evolution in her book 'Het internet is stuk (maar we kunnen het repareren)' (The internet is broken, but we can fix it). Originally known as the 'Society for Old and New Media,' Waag has transformed into a Future Lab exploring the intersection of technology, art, and science.

Today, Waag Futurelab is dedicated to crafting a sustainable, equitable society through collective research on emerging technologies and challenging cultural norms. Waag Futurelab experiment, design, and advocate for alternatives rooted in public values, fostering an open, fair, and inclusive future in collaboration with civil society.

nodes.name: INOVA
bio: INOVA+ is a consultancy company that for 25 years has supported the growth of organisations through innovation, international cooperation, digital transformation, and access to funding. INOVA+ is the Portuguese leading company in the field of the promotion, management, dissemination, and exploitation of international projects on Innovation, Training and Research & Technological Development, having supported over 500 organizations across various sectors, managed more than 300 projects, and coordinated more than 30 European projects.

The company brings together and has access to a multidisciplinary team, comprised of professionals with proven experience in data collection and analysis, training, monitoring, digital technology development, designers, among others. The focus is on people and projects that contribute to mastering the social, ecological, and economic challenges the EU faces.

nodes.name: Royal College of Art
bio: The Royal College of Art is the UK’s only entirely postgraduate university of art and design, dedicated to teaching, research and knowledge exchange with industry. Founded in 1837, the Royal College of Art is the world’s largest community of postgraduate art and design students. It is also the oldest art and design university in continuous operation and has been ranked as the world's number one art and design university for eleven consecutive years, according to the QS World University Rankings by Subject 2025 – the worldwide survey of academic and industry opinion.

The College is located on three sites in central London, in Battersea, Kensington, and White City. Noteworthy alumni include Sir James Dyson, Thomas Heatherwick, David Hockney, Tracey Emin, Christopher Bailey, Julien McDonald, Margaret Calvert, Alison Jackson, Idris Khan, Sir Quentin Blake, Sir David Adjaye, Suzie Templeton and Sir Ridley Scott.

nodes.name: University College Dublin
bio: University College Dublin (UCD) is one of Europe's leading research-intensive universities; bringing undergraduate education, masters and PhD training, research, innovation, and community engagement together. Since its foundation, the University has made a unique contribution to the creation of modern Ireland, based on successful engagement with Irish society on every level and across every sphere of activity.

The international standing of UCD has grown in recent years; it is currently ranked within the top 1% of higher education institutions worldwide. UCD is also Ireland's most globally engaged university with over 38,000 students drawn from 152 countries, including over 5,000 students based at locations outside of Ireland.

The University's main Dublin campus occupies a parkland estate of 133 hectares and offers world-leading facilities including the UCD O'Brien Centre for Science, UCD Sutherland School of Law, UCD Lochlan Quinn School of Business, UCD Moore Centre for Business, and the UCD Student Centre.

nodes.name: Confluence of European Water Bodies
bio: A grassroots, growing community of care and concern, the Confluence of European Water Bodies which aims to foster new dialogues and relationships with water.

nodes.name: SciArt: Science Art Society
bio: The JRC SciArt project, founded in 2016, brokers and curates transdisciplinary exchanges and encounters between art science and policy within the JRC and wider European Commission. Resonances is their main initative. Informed by cutting-edge scientific research and public policy discussions, the aim of Resonances IV is to explore contemporary societal concerns with a transdisciplinary approach. Spurred by artists and creatives around the world we want to develop discourse, visions, artworks and exhibition that raise questions, change perceptions and widen awareness, that can trigger systemic change in support of the European Commission’s Green Deal.

nodes.name: Natura2000
bio: There are over 27 000 nature sites protected by EU legislation. These form the Natura 2000 network.
Natura 2000 sites reflect Europe's rich variety of wildlife and habitats. They cover almost one fifth of land and one tenth of surrounding seas - which is about the size of Spain and Italy combined.

The sites range in size from less then one hectare to hundreds of square kilometres. Sites include several strictly protected nature reserves, and habitat types such as forests, grasslands, wetlands and coastal and marine habitats.
For over 30 years, the Birds and Habitats Directives (the 'Nature Directives') have set out the overall legal framework for protecting and managing Natura 2000 sites.

nodes.name: Furtherfield
bio: We organise for inclusivity and equity in art and technology and advocate for their use in imagining and building real social change and positive environmental impact.

For over 25 years, through nearly 70 exhibitions, and over 125 national/international partnerships, we have developed alternative systems of co-creation and co-organisation across digital and physical networks.

nodes.name: Future Focus21c
bio: Future Focus21c (FF21C) employ innovative, creative strategies to foster profound learning through tangible, evidence-based activities across three pillars of work: Research, Innovation and Delivery in education and community contexts. By tapping into and cultivating the creativity of learners, individuals and professionals FF21C aim to instil innovative thinking that is applicable across various domains and locally relevant, appropriate and context-responsive.

Their goal is to equip individuals for the challenges of the 21st century by providing experiences that facilitate the development of both content knowledge and practical skills with real-world applications. Collaborating with fellow researchers, they strive to reimagine various facets of contemporary life, aligning education, lifelong learning and professional development with the needs of society.

Their comprehensive approach represents Ireland's sole research-driven, evidence-based, systemic, and integrated programmes and approaches, encompassing place-based STEAM education, circular design thinking in solution-oriented projects, inquiry-based learning, and alignment with Sustainable Development Goals and the Earth Charter.

nodes.name: SMARTlab
bio: SMARTlab promotes user-driven, transdisciplinary research, leveraging Creative Technology Innovations for social change.

For three decades, SMARTlab has run an award-winning practice-based PhD programme and delivered high-impact research, development and innovation programmes and projects. SMARTlab aims to bring together the brightest minds across disciplines and to provide them with the tools they need to contribute to solving real-world problems and building sustainable solutions.

SMARTlab specialises in developing ground-up technology solutions for people of all levels of cognitive and physical ability, from mainstream learners of all ages to 'special' and 'gifted' learners and lifelong learners in the developed and developing worlds. The aim is to transform lives through providing unlimited access to education and tools for creative expression.

nodes.name: Helen Hamlyn Centre
bio: The Helen Hamlyn Centre for Design is a global leader in inclusive design and works with government, business, academia and the third sector to conduct research and knowledge exchange projects. The Helen Hamlyn Centre for design is the RCA’s longest-standing research centre, a global leader in inclusive design.

nodes.name: Loughborough University
bio: Loughborough University is a public research university in Loughborough, Leicester. It has a London campus. It ranks No 1 for Sports (QS subject ranking), and is a top ten UK university for undergraduate education.

nodes.name: Tongji University
bio: Established in 1907 by German physicians in Shanghai, Tongji University is a comprehensive university, renowned for design and engineering. It is located in Shanghai, China. The university is one of the 211, 985 and the Double First-Class elite.

nodes.name: Mimar Sinan Fine Art University
bio: Mimar Sinan Fine Arts University is the oldest public art university in Istanbul, Turkey

nodes.name: University of the Creative Arts
bio: UCA is the specialist creative arts university in the UK, offering undergraduate and postgraduate degree courses in Creative Arts, Business and Technology. It is based in Caterbury, UK.

nodes.name: NEoN Digital Arts
bio: NEoN Digital Arts (SCIO) advocates for digital art and technology while at the same time addressing the negatives aspects that can often arise from their use. We provide access to expertise and equipment in a safe, inclusive environment, using free, open-source or low cost software while simultaneously explaining the ethical issues surrounding their construction, use and disposal.

nodes.name: Access Space
bio: Access Space is an arts and education organisation, where people interested in art, design, computers, recycling, music, electronics, photography and more, meet like-minded people, share and develop skills. We engage with and encourage a very broad section of the community to get involved with artistic, creative and technical projects.

nodes.name: Brunel University of London
bio: As one of the UK’s foremost technical universities, Brunel has a rich history of world-leading research, innovation and teaching excellence. It is a member of the University of London. It is the 1st Most International University in the UK and in the top 10% for social and environmental impact research. It was founded in 1966. It is a member of the University of London.
